title: A graphical experiment of exponential spread
description_1: A real-time javascript simulation of epidemic spreading on a network
description_2: Built to provide intuition for spreading in constrained environments
description_3: All parameters related to spread are tunable

title: DataDrivenCV package
description_1: An R package for building a CV/Resume from a spreadsheet of information
description_2: Built around the [pagedown](https://pagedown.rbind.io/) package in R
description_3: Framework supplied by package is entirely self-sufficient so user's are not dependent on package version changes.

title: Phewas-ME
description_1: Shiny app for exploring results of Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PheWAS)
description_2: Allows user to look directly at individual data generating results to identify spurious or novel associations.
description_3: Build as R package framework allowing modular construction of apps based upon a projects needs.

title: t-SNE explained in plain javascript
description_1: Full implementation and explaination of t-sne visualization algorithm
description_2: Featured in "Explorables" section of Observable

title: Javascript Statistics Snippets
description_1: A series of small self-contained functions for doing statistical computation in javascript
description_2: Functions are optimized for speed along with legibility

title: Shinysense
description_1: A set of shiny modules for letting shiny sense the world around it.
description_2: Currently has touch, sound, motion, and vision 'senses.'
description_3: Bundled into an R package.

title: What are P-Values, Really?
description_1: A resource for explaining what statistical significance really means.
description_2: Storified to try and make it memorable.
description_3: Takes the form of a reproducible r-markdown document so others can recreate

title: Data Visualization Best Practices in R
description_1: Intermediate level course exploring visualization best practices in R.
description_2: Uses ggplot2 and the tidyverse packages.
description_3: See the story [A Multimillion-Dollar Startup Hid A Sexual Harassment Incident By Its CEO](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/daveyalba/datacamp-sexual-harassment-metoo-tech-startup) for information on why I no longer actively promote this course.

title: Making Nice Looking Websites Using RMarkdown
description_1: A walkthrough from start to finish of making a website using RMarkdown and hosting it on Github.
description_2: Made in collaboration with Lucy McGowan
description_3: Presented at the statistical computing workshop for Vanderbilt Medical Center

title: Conditional Survival Curves on Truncated Survival Data
description_1: A visual exploration of Kaplin-Meier survival curves on left-truncated survival data.
description_2: Drag the conditional slider to see how the survival curve changes depending on the age of entry.
description_3: All logic for K-M curve written from scratch in javascript and much more performant than the survival package in R.
description_4: For more information on the algorithm to generate a K-M curve see the wikipedia page.

title: Reusable Statistics Plots in D3
description_1: Also see my histogram made in the same way.
description_2: My first attempts at making a d3 library.
description_3: Ultimately will be tied with a companion R app for interactive visualization for statisticians.
description_4: Uses the reusable d3 structure proposed by Elliot Bentely.

title: What's In Season?
description_1: An interactive exploration of what produce is in season.
description_2: Data scraped from here using python.
description_3: Allows the user to select different in season ingredients and search for recipes containing them.
description_4: Notebooks for scraping in github repo.

title: Data Visualization In R
description_1: Rmarkdown document for a statistical computing workshop I gave at Vanderbilt.
description_2: A brief overview of some common visualization mistakes and code to fix them in ggplot
description_3: Provides an overview of some newer visualization tools.

title: Binomially Distributed Fun!
description_1: Demonstrates how a sequence of independent Bernoulli Trials make up the Binomial Distribution.
description_2: Allows the user to toggle the parameters of the Bernoulli and generate a samples.
description_3: Calculates and displays a 95% confidence interval and wilson hypothesis test based upon the generated data.
description_4: All statistics funtions are written from scratch in vanilla javascript.

title: The Likelihood Function
description_1: An interactive exploration of the likelihood function.
description_2: Visually explains the concepts of support intervals and likelihood ratios.
description_3: Allows the user to input their own data for creating figures for reports/presentations.

title: Confidence Intervals Explained
description_1: Allows the user to explore what a frequentist confidence interval truly is.
description_2: To many people, including the scientists who use them, the behavior of Confidence Intervals is confusing.
description_3: All statistics functions are written from base javascript. See github repo for code.

title: Probability Integral Transformations
description_1: Made in an effort to visualize what happens when you transform a probability distribution with a function.
description_2: Uses the normal distribution transformed by the normal cdf, resulting in a uniform distribution. See here for more info.
description_3: Inspired by my course work in Probability at Vanderbilt.

title: Where Are Wildfires Burning?
description_1: Uses open data from NASA satelites on global temperature anomalies.
description_2: Fresh data is downloaded every day and pushed to the static page via shell scripts avoiding the need for servers.
description_3: Data source.

title: Interactive Manhattan Plot R Package.
description_1: An R package to generate interactive and embedable manhattan plots for genome wide association studies.
description_2: Binds R and Javascript + D3 using the HTMLWidgets package.
description_3: NA

title: State Farmers Market Profiles.
description_1: Companion visualization to What Do Farmer's Markets Sell?
description_2: Explore different states path's through different metrics relating to farmers markets.
description_3: Uses equal sized states map as menu to reduce bias associated with normal projections.

title: What Do Farmer's Markets Sell?
description_1: Select different good types (e.g. Vegetables, Fruit) and see which markets sell them.
description_2: Assemble different combinations of goods to explore regional trends.
description_3: Dynamic layout adjusts to mobile or desktop views.
description_4: Be patient with it, more than eight thousand points are being drawn to the screen. It will bog down older phones/computers.

title: Interactive Manhattan Plot Viewer.
description_1: Developed as an experiment in exploratory data visualization.
description_2: Select different controls for comparison, e.g. non-dominant arm growth to see linked snps.
description_3: A manhattan plot is a commonly used tool in accessing genetic roots for traits
description_4: Uses data from the FAMuSS study ( Thompson Et Al. 2004).

title: Learn ASL numbers with Leap Motion.
description_1: First place project at 2014 UVM CS Fair.
description_2: Teaches numbers 0-9 in American Sign Language.
description_3: Utilizes three.js and webGL for rendering.
description_4: Built to exploit multiple HCI and Cognitive Psychology theories (e.g. object consistancy and the generation effect) in order to maximize learning experience.

title: Experimental Leap Motion + D3.js project.
description_1: Wave your hands around and watch D3.js mirror you!
description_2: Requires a leap motion device.
description_3: In the future I plan on implementing ways to interact with D3 visualizations by recognizing gestures using machine learning algorithms.
description_4: Video of it in action for if you don't have a Leap.
description_5: Note: When using, start by waving your hands around above the Leap Motion device and watch it calibrate!

title: Polio's impact on the United States.
description_1: A project for Data Science 2 (Math 295) taught by Professor James Bagrow at the University of Vermont.
description_2: iPython notebook and data files available on my github.
description_3: NA

title: labinthewild.org Interactive Visualization.
description_1: A visualization developed for LabInTheWild at the University of Michigan to help participants place themselves among differing demographics.
description_2: NA
description_3: NA

title: Alternative energy filling stations in the U.S..
description_1: Using d3.hexbin I took took 18k+ data points and binned them to help explore geographic trends in alternative energy filling stations.
description_2: NA
description_3: NA

title: Marvel Vs. DC in the theater.
description_1: I extracted data from The Verge article <a href='http://www.theverge.com/2014/8/22/6056617/marvels-movie-business-is-crushing-dcs-and-its-not-close' target='_blank'> 'Marvel's movie business is crushing DC's and it's not close.'
description_2: NA
description_3: NA

title: Where does California get its energy?
description_1: A visualization that explores how electricity is generated in the state of California. Data was cleaned using python and then the visualization was generated using d3.js.
description_2: NA
description_3: NA
